utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Where are those projections?

utterance.speaker: Robin
utterance.content: 3, 6, and 9 are in your folders.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Can I have some more –

utterance.speaker: Robin
utterance.content: Tea’s at your seat.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Excellent.

utterance.speaker: Robin
utterance.content: Hello? Oh, hold on. Ben Federman again. Another pre-call.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: We did the pre-call. This is the post-pre-call-call?

utterance.speaker: Ben
utterance.content: Board’s gonna want some specifics for the push into the Asian market.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Ben, there are no specifics about Asia. We came up with that as a Hail Mary at three in the morning to placate the board about International!

utterance.speaker: Ben
utterance.content: Carly, I’m just giving you a heads-up about Asia.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: There is no Asia.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Let’s talk about Asia. We’re in the preliminary stages of forming a strategic alliance with Credit Lyonnais. Within three months you won’t be able to walk four feet in Kyung Hong, South Korea, without seeing one of our beautiful models smiling at you from billboards and drugstore windows inviting you in.

utterance.speaker: Boardmember
utterance.content: That’s incredible news, Carly. We’d hoped to hear something about Asia, but had no idea plans were so far along.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Well, you know Asia. Nothing’s done until it’s done.

utterance.speaker: Boardmember
utterance.content: Carly, I was wondering, could you walk us through what you were thinking for other Asian territories?

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Absolutely. India has over half a billion women. In terms of spending power it’s the single largest potential market in the world. Um, we have retained a local firm to ensure that cultural differences are respected, um, however, I can’t go into the specifics of my plan with you until tomorrow; right now I have a meeting and I need the room.

utterance.speaker: Boardmember 2
utterance.content: We were just getting started.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I know, and I do apologize. It’s last minute, but the meeting is with three State Department officials to smooth the way for China.

utterance.speaker: Boardmember
utterance.content: China? This is just incredible.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: We’ll be in touch.

utterance.speaker: Boardmember
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Robin
utterance.content: What is it?

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I need a doctor. I can’t move my leg!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 32-year-old female, paralysis and severe pain in her right quad. Go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How’d she get to you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s the CEO of Sonyo Cosmetics. Three assistants and fifteen VPs checked out who should be treating her. Who da man? I da man. I always suspected.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House, I know the chances are very slim, but I’m sure you recognize that she may have what you had: a clot in her thigh.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A bit of a long shot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What about a disc herniation?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t know, Eric. If her disc were herniated, she’d present with pain elsewhere, wouldn’t she?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, I suppose.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re right, a clot’s also the most deadly, right, Robert?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: True. The clot breaks off, she could stroke and die.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House, I believe that they’re right, and –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stop talking.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You read one of those negotiating books, didn’t you? “Getting to Yes: Fifty Ways to Win an Argument.” “The Hitchhiker’s Guide to Being a Pal.” In five seconds you just manipulated these two into agreeing with your point of view. Fellas, this is known as “soft positional bargaining.” It’s not gonna work.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House, are you saying that she doesn’t have a clot or are you saying that if she does have a clot she doesn’t need blood thinners and an angiogram?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase, put her on blood thinners, do an angiogram. When that comes back negative, MRI the spine. If that’s clean, cut her open and biopsy the leg.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Excellent suggestion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Read less, more TV.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s rare for an individual to make a donation significant enough to impact an organization as large and unwieldy as a hospital. This donation does come with one string: that he be made Chairman of the Board. I think that’s a reasonable request. I think he should have the right to know what it is we do with his $100 million. Please welcome our new Chairman of the Board, Edward Vogler.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Thank you, thank you. When I was eighteen, my dad loaned me $20, 000 for a college tuition which he would have known was a mistake had he known that I wasn’t actually in college. I took his money and invested in a friend who had a little business, and when my dad found out what I had done with his money, he and I didn’t talk much after that. But my friend’s business took off, and I used the profits from that to buy another company, and another, and I must have been pretty good at it, had a good eye, because before I knew it people were making offers for my company. And, uh, about a year ago I went public and overnight I was worth a billion dollars. So I went to see my dad. I’ll admit, I wanted a little payback, you know, kind of shove the wind in his face, so I went upstate and sat in the kitchen I grew up in and, uh, he had no reaction. It wasn’t his fault, he didn’t even know who I was. Because his Alzheimer’s had taken a turn for the worse, despite the best drugs and care out there, and that is why I’m here. What if my contribution to this hospital is the difference between no cure and a cure for cancer? The difference between a man not recognizing his wife of 35 years and being able to look at her and say, “Good morning, honey. I love you.” If there’s a disease out there killing people, I am writing you a blank check to fight back. So, things are going to change, a lot.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m gonna have to ask you for the cell phone?

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Do what you need to do, I’m okay.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pretty sure my x-ray machine can take your phone in a fight. It’ll fry it.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Fine.

utterance.speaker: Jenny
utterance.content: How old is she?

utterance.speaker: Jenny
utterance.content: Wow. She’s already the CEO of a public company.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s a workaholic. Okay Carly, hold still. The x-ray machine is gonna pass over your leg.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Jenny
utterance.content: What’d you do with your time off?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Snowboarding in Gstaad.

utterance.speaker: Jenny
utterance.content: Switzerland!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Do you ski or board? You can come with, if you like.

utterance.speaker: Jenny
utterance.content: Maybe we should start with a drink before we go ‘round the world.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh, you want to have a drink with me? Oooh, very aggressive! I like that.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I want to run this place like a business.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What, you want to put more vending machines in the hallway? Maybe a roulette wheel?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Nice one. But I’m serious. The product that you’re selling is good health, it shouldn’t be a tough sell. You don’t want to sell, it means people don’t care about your product. You care if people are healthy, or are you too proud for that? Who’s that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That’s, uh, just one of our doctors.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Aren’t doctors supposed to wear lab coats.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He’s… different.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Everyone’s buddy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, not exactly.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Then why does he get away with it?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s just a coat. He’s very good.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Hmm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Say “ah”.

utterance.speaker: Ricky
utterance.content: Ah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, really belt it out, like you’re gonna throw up.

utterance.speaker: Rick
utterance.content: Ah!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Perfect. Okay, that’s it. We should know in a couple of days what’s growing in your son’s throat. Hello?

utterance.speaker: Ricky
utterance.content: He can’t talk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Excuse me?

utterance.speaker: Ricky
utterance.content: He had knee surgery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right…

utterance.speaker: Ricky
utterance.content: About a year ago, and then he couldn’t talk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, yeah, well, that happens. You know, it’s very dangerous operating so close to the vocal chords. Okay, well, we’ll send your kid’s culture to the lab and somebody will call you. BOO!

utterance.speaker: Ricky
utterance.content: AAH!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just wanted to see if your dad, uh, sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I need you to wear your lab coat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need two days of outrageous sex with someone obscenely younger than you. Like half your age.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Wear the coat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Man oh man. Someone got spanked real good this morning.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Guy gives $100 million to cure cancer, pretty small concession to wear a lab coat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cure cancer. Is the hospital getting out of the dull business of treating patients?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You know that’s not what he’s doing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know exactly what he’s doing. He’s using us to run clinical trials.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, shame on him! Saving lives like that!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s unethical. Oh, are you coming in, too? I thought I had you convinced.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Clinical trials save thousands of lives.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s using patients as guinea pigs.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Pharmaceutical companies do that every day.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are we a pharmaceutical company? We’re gonna wind up pressuring desperate patients into choices that are bad for them, good for us. You’re gonna compromise patient care.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Who the hell am I talking to? Suddenly ethical lapses are a major concern for you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s interesting is it suddenly doesn’t bother you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So, if you ignore ethics to save one person it’s admirable, but if you do it to save a thousand you’re a bastard. All he’s done is taken your game and gone pro.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s not going to kill a few patients. He’s going to kill this hospital.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It took him three seconds to size you up, and surprise? He doesn’t like you. Wear the damn coat.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hello. I’m Dr. Foreman, I work with Dr. House. Our initial tests say you’re fine. We think you may have had a clot but it resolved on its own, so we’re gonna keep you overnight to be safe and you can go back home tomorrow. Or, back to work. Hey, you okay. Get in here! I need a line in her, IV morphine, stat!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Get any read on the new Chairman of the Board?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, he took your parking space.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s not necessarily bad news.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Do you ever watch “Gilligan’s Island” reruns and really, really think they’re gonna get off the island this time?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We should introduce ourselves. It couldn’t hurt.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Make him a bundt cake. Patient hit a ten on the pain scale. What would explain that?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There was no clot in her leg, the angio was totally clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What about the muscle biopsy?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No neurogenic or myopathic abnormalities.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s also negative for trichinosis, no toxoplasmosis or polyarteritis nodosa.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Robert, what was her sedimentation rate?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Normal, Allison, therefore no inflammation, no immunologic response.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you mind sharing that number with me?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fifteen, Allison.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Are you mocking me?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Duh, Allison.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m just suggesting we look outside the box. What if her sed rate is elevated?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, let’s go further outside the box. Let’s say the angio revealed a clot, and let’s say we treated that clot, and now she’s all better, and personally thanked me by performing –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: My Aunt Elisa lives in Philiadelphia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, it’s storytime! Let me get my baba.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her normal temperature is 96.2, not 98.6 like you and me. If her temperature were 98.6, she’d have a fever. I’m just wondering if you think we could apply the same logic to Carly’s sed rate.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s absurd. I love it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If 15 is high for Carly, then she has inflammation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which could, in turn, mean cancer. I’ll talk to Wilson. Next time, skip Aunt Elisa.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re probably talking about a primary bone cancer. Can be tricky to detect, you’ll need a bone scan –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s why I’m talking to an oncologist.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Sure, I’ve nothing better to do besides departmental meetings and budget reports… new Chairman of the Board, you know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh! I hadn’t heard.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Right. Clinical trials…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Completely unethical.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And a very bad omen for you. There’s not much money in curing African sleeping sickness.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I have seen every scary movie ever made. Six-year-old twins in front of an elevator of blood, boys’ choirs: those are bad omens. This is much more mundane: a billionaire wants to get laid.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Billionaires buy movie studios to get laid. They buy hospitals to get respect.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And the reason you want respect?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: To… get laid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay then. You’ve just gotta think like a billionaire. Let’s see, big scary changes, and then, “Oh, Dr. Cameron, we should have dinner to discuss your future on my G-5 private jet.”

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, come on. You know how good you have it here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, I’m the big poobah, the big cheese, the go-to guy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You do the cases you want to do, when you want to do them. You’re not going to get that anywhere else.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax, I’ve been through three regime changes in this hospital. Every time, same story.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Just keep your head down, that’s all I’m saying. And put on your coat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It itches. So, are you going to do this bone scan for me or what?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Simpson! Did you hear? New management. I’m thinking about switching to orthopedics. How much do you guys get for massage now, without the happy ending?

utterance.speaker: Simpson
utterance.content: Dr. House, what do you want?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You remember a guy named Van Der Meer? Not a big talker. You fixed his ACL.

utterance.speaker: Simpson
utterance.content: Well, not according to my medical malpractice premiums.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Didn’t get hypertensive during surgery? No strokes? Maybe some connectivity loss?

utterance.speaker: Simpson
utterance.content: What, you’re going to get involved now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not involved. Guy brought his son into the clinic.

utterance.speaker: Simpson
utterance.content: I didn’t touch the son. I’m not taking any responsibility there.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The son’s fine. Can’t shut him up. The dad show any signs of cortical disease? Wernicke’s?

utterance.speaker: Simpson
utterance.content: No. Nothing. And that’s why we settled; because we couldn’t find anything. The guy got over a million dollars, don’t tell me he’s complaining.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s not saying “boo”.

utterance.speaker: Robin
utterance.content: Your father wants to know when you’ll be back from your trip.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Email back. It’s “taking longer than I thought.” He doesn’t need to see me like this.

utterance.speaker: Robin
utterance.content: What about your brother?

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hello. I’m Dr. Wilson. I was –

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Robin, I’m going to need a minute.

utterance.speaker: Robin
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Thank you. There are two Dr. Wilsons in the hospital. One in ophthalmology and one in cancer. My eyes are fine, so you’re here to tell me I have cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There’s no cancer in your bone.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: You’re not smiling.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There’s something called referred pain. You could have cancer in one part of your body that presents in another. Given your age and your family history, I’m thinking your colon.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Great. I was at Columbia when my mom died. Now there’s a blast. Cleaning up her vomit and running to my econ final. Look, if I’m a short-timer give me drugs, I’ll go back to work, I’ll die there.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Whoa. There’s a quick test to see if you even have it, a colonoscopy.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I know how you do that test.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If you have colon cancer, we can treat it, it’s early.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: That’s what they told my mom. She was dead six months later.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re a smart person about to make a very bad decision. You know, cancer treatment’s come a long way in twelve years, but if you don’t do this now –

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I don’t want to be looked at!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There is another way. We could do a virtual colonoscopy. Basically, we do a CT scan of your colon. It’s non-invasive, but it’s very expensive. I assume that’s not a problem. Say yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mr. Van Der Meer. What? Relax, Ricky’s going to be just “finkf”. Strep throat, here’s a prescription for an antibiotic. He should be all better in a few days. Although, this might sting a little. I want to see you again real soon.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Virtual colonoscopy was clean. No colon cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What happened to a regular old-fashioned colonoscopy?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She was uncomfortable doing any more tests! I had to convince her to do that one!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you get that often? Women would rather die than get naked with you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She’s scared.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But not of tests. Just embarrassing ones.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not an inflammatory process, it’s not a clot because Chase’s angio says so, and it’s not cancer because her toosh is perfect. Anybody else got an Aunt Elisa with weird stuff?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe it’s worth looking into –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought you said Carly’s angio was clean.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It was clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You guys see the problem here?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s no indication of any abnormalities. No lesions, no spurs, no masses –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Her toes are screwed up. They’re backwards. Do you guys know how much surgery it’s going to take to swap them back?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either she literally has two left feet or you angio-ed the wrong leg.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That’s impossible. It can’t be the wrong –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or maybe it was Jenny! How come some resident signed this radiology form? Were you even in the room?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll redo her angio straight away –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ll do nothing! Foreman, you do the angiogram.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I can’t believe I did that.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Why do we have to redo the angiogram?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There was a shadow on the first test.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: A shadow? A shadow means there could be a blood clot, right? I read Conn’s Current Therapy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Real page turner. No, it’s not that kind of shadow.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: My chest hurts.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s from the tracer I injected. Might also get a little nauseous, or have a metallic taste, all normal.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I’m a runner. I shouldn’t feel like this.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Carly, I’m looking at your vitals right now, and –

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I can’t breathe.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Carly?

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: My chest… My chest.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Respiratory arrest, call the code.

utterance.speaker: Tech
utterance.content: What’ve you got?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s drowning.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Foreman did a thoracentesis to drain the fluid from her lungs. They sent the fluid to the lab, it’ll be back in a few hours. You’ll be happy to know that Chase’s mistake didn’t cost her. Angio revealed no clot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m thrilled.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay, see, now you’re just being stubborn. It’s cold, perfectly good excuse to wear your lab coat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Carly needs a heart transplant.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Thoracentesis revealed a transudate?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Haven’t gotten it back yet.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Her MUGA scan, what was the ejection fracture? Maybe you could treat it, surgically.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Haven’t done the MUGA.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How do you know she needs a heart transplant?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I got my aura read today. It said someone close to me had a broken heart.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Since when do I need the secret pass code to talk to you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t tell you anything. Professional responsibility.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Like that matters to you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not my professional responsibility, yours. New regime, you gotta keep your head down, too.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Now, that’s good thinking, because I was going to go right to Cuddy and rat you out as soon as you were done talking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not saying you want to, I’m saying you’d be obligated to.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Because of my position on the Board? Because of my position on the transplant committee? Hey, you brought this up for a reason. You need to talk to me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You sure you’re doing the right thing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve come up with a few really great rationalizations.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sorry to interrupt. We have a problem.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thoracentesis revealed a transudate. We did an echo. She’s in severe congestive heart failure. She needs a heart transplant. We’ll get her on the list immediately –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s already on the list.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Come in.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Thanks. What is a “Department of Diagnostic Medicine”?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That’s Dr. House’s department. They deal with cases that other doctors can’t figure out.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: It’s a financial black hole. Department costs us $3 million a year, treat one patient a week.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He saves one patient per week.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: What about everyone else? His department’s not going to find the cure for breast cancer.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Uh, maybe not, but –

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Are you sleeping with House?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What? No.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: But you did, right? A long time ago?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That’s an incredibly inappropriate question.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: If your judgment is compromised by prior or current relationship, that is my business.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I respect him, that is all you need to know.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: He’s still not wearing a coat.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, I told him –

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I’m sure you did. And yet, he’s not wearing it. I’m just wondering if that’s a reflection on him, or on you.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: You’re Dr. House. I found a picture of you online at a conference –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You need a heart transplant.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I run, I work out, I –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You cut yourself. Probably highly ritualized. You play the same Sarah MacLaughlin song over and over while you do it, probably works better than anti-depressants.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I don’t understand how that has to –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re a high-powered bulimic. You make yourself throw up. You have to find the most efficient way to vomit without revealing the tell-tale signs of bulimia, which is all, eugh. Very unseemly, for a CEO. So, you found a common antidote for accidental poisoning to do the job: ipecac. Which is great, if your kid’s just swallowed a bottle of aspirin, but really, really bad if it’s a habit. It causes muscle damage. It caused the pain in your leg. And it destroyed your heart. How often do you do it?

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Three times a week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In about an hour, there’s going to be an emergency meeting of the transplant committee to discuss where you fall on the list should a new heart become available. Problem is, I am required to tell the committee of your bulimia, it’s a major psychiatric condition. Ranks right up there with suicidal, makes you a very bad risk.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: So you’re here to tell me I have just a few hours to live?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless I lie to the committee. But if they find out, I lose my medical license. This would be a very good time to offer me a bribe. How much is your life worth, how much is my job worth –

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Why are you here doing this to me? What do you want?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want to know what’s right.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Am I worth it? You think I’m pathetic. Has a good job, everything in the world, but she just doesn’t like the way that she looks –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, stop hiding! I’m asking you if you want to live or die, you can’t even say that!

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: What do you want me to do? Cry?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes! I want you to tell me that your life is important to you, because I don’t know! Because that’s what’s on the table right now: your life.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: I don’t want to die. I don’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This 32-year-old female was admitted by my staff because of paralysis and pain in her right thigh. Patient rapidly deteriorated and now has severe congestive heart failure. Pressers and vasodilators have not improved her conditions whatsoever. Pulmonary function tests show an FVC of over 3 liters with EDD-1 of at least 90% of predicted. And preserved FEB/FEC ratio and preserved DLCO as well. Her MUGA had an ejection fraction of 19% with no focal wall or motion abnormalities. Heart catheterization revealed clean left, right and circumflex arteries, and subsequent biopsy revealed irreversible cardiomyopathy. Which is why we’re here.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Uh, Dr. House, I’m confused by your time and date stamps. It appears that you put Carly on the transplant list before you did these tests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had a hunch.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You don’t have hunches. You know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look, if the tests had come back differently, obviously I would have taken her off the lists, but on the long shot… On the long shot I was right, I didn’t want to waste time.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Is there any exclusion criteria we should know about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: CAT scan revealed no tumors and Dr. Wilson found no trace of cancer.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What about any other criteria?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No atherosclerotic vascular disease –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are there any –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No pneumonia, no bacteriemia, no Hep-B or C or any other letters.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Substance abuse? Any history of –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No alcohol, no drugs.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Any psychiatric conditions, history of depression –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s a little blue, but turns out she needs a heart transplant.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. House, if you subvert or mislead this committee, you will be subject to disciplinary action.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Cuddy, do you have any reason to think that I would lie?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I simply want you to answer the question! Is there anything on the recipient exclusion criteria that would disqualify your patient from getting a heart?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Beautiful organ donor weather.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You lied, didn’t you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I never lie.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Big mistake.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then you should have voted against putting her on the list.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re my friend.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, jeez. Have some backbone. If you think I’m wrong, do something.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wait, you’re getting mad at me for sticking up for you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You value our friendship more than your ethical responsibilities.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Our friendship is an ethical responsibility. What is it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My patient’s getting a heart.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s not gonna fire you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’d fire you. Bye bye.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If I screw up, the patient dies… I’ll never get another job.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So go stick your head between your legs and lick your wounds in Stadt.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, I like it here. You guys don’t think it’s weird House knew the patient needed a heart transplant before we did any heart tests?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s House. He knows things.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: But usually, he’s putting it in our face, telling us how cleverly he figured it out. This time, nothing. Just “I had a hunch.”

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It is weird.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: Okay, ready for the donor heart.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: They just stopped Carly’s heart. And your dumb patient –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They’re all – oh, the guy who can’t talk.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Mr. Van Der Meer, he scheduled an appointment to see you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oooh, goody.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I wanted you to know Chase is worried you’re going to fire him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s bad enough that screw-ups cost lives. Now we’ve got Vogler, screw-ups cost jobs. I want Chase scared. I want him doing everything he can to protect his job.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House, if you were in his position wouldn’t you be more likely to perform well if you were reassured and –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, will you stop it with the book! Why are you doing this?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not doing anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re manipulating everyone.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: People… dismiss me. Because I’m a woman, because I’m pretty, because I’m not aggressive. My opinions shouldn’t be rejected just because people don’t like me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They like you. Everyone likes you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you? I have to know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 5 hours, 23 minutes, that’s fast.

utterance.speaker: Robin
utterance.content: Is that good or bad?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It depends. Either surgery went really well, or it ended really abruptly.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: Textbook. She’ll outlive us all.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, sing for me. Oh, no, no, no, no… come on, look. When you had your surgery, you were intubated. Surgeon stuck a tube down your throat. Now, it never happens, and it’s never caught, but it happens. Your vocal chords were paralyzed. I treated the spastic dysphonia with Botox. Ironically, a substance that tightens every other corner of your face actually loosens the tongue. I have healed you. You can talk. Oh, well. BOOOO! Okay, you don’t have to say anything, it can be our little secret. If you can talk, blink twice. But you’re not going to, because you think you won’t be entitled to the money you won in the settlement with Simpson. Yesterday I would have said you’d have to give the money back. Today… hospital’s come into a lot of money, mum’s the word.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know the cardiologist has given you some guidelines, schedule of medications, and a strict diet: just what someone with an eating disorder needs. So, I thought I’d get you started. Fried chicken from the Carnegie Deli.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: You’re kidding.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. Actually, I got it downstairs.

utterance.speaker: Carly
utterance.content: Why did you fight for me? You risked so much, and you hardly know me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re my patient. Don’t screw it up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Love this part! Okay. He ruined it.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Just wanted to stop by and introduce myself. I’m Edward Vogler, new Chairman of the Board. In a way, I guess that makes me your boss.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am sorry about the lab coat thing. The dry cleaners destroyed it.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: That was my very first heart transplant meeting, very exciting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Trust me. Six Flags, way more exciting.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Patient’s very lucky to have such a passionate doctor who stands up for what he believes in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sweet of you to say.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Yeah. ‘Fraid you’ve been duped, though. The nurse found this in the patient’s purse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, my. If only I’d known.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Tough being a doctor. You’ve got all that power. The power to play God.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, I don’t envy the transplant committee their responsibility. They basically would have been forced to kill that poor girl. I’m not sure I could have done that.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: This is not a game to me, Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. This is actually more like we’re dancing right now, so let’s get to the point. You don’t like me. I’m pretty sure I’m not going to like you. It’s nothing personal, I don’t like anybody. But none of that really matters, does it, because you’ve got money, and I’ve got tenure. You need full board approval to get rid of me. I’ve got Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And Wilson. So, as long as we’re stuck with each other, we might as well ignore each other. That wasn’t nearly as dramatic as I was hoping.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I looked into that tenure thing, and you’re right. It’s actually easier for me to get rid of a board member like Cuddy or Wilson than to get rid of a doctor. That’s interesting, isn’t it?
